prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I kick my adult ”stepdaughter” out of my house?
New here so if I haven’t understood one of the rules please let me know!

I have a tricky situation I’m going through as of late.  I’m in a long term relationship.  We aren’t technically married, but we live as we are.  After a messy divorce she was never interested in being married again.  We’ve been dating for 8 years now.  I told her that the engagement is the best part so I proposed with both of us understanding that we would never actually get married.  She has an adult daughter who lives with us.  She’s 19. 

My “stepdaughter” and I have never had a good relationship despite my best efforts.  I really gave it everything I could to improve it over the years, but at best she was indifferent to me.  I gave up trying after buying her a car for her 16th birthday and she thanked her mother and didn’t acknowledge me at all even after her mother told her that I alone bought it for her.  

After that I’ve been just waiting her out for the most part.  I’m still kind when I’m around her, but if this is the relationship with me she wants then so be it.  I always assumed that when she turned 18 she would go off to school somewhere.  I was unfortunately wrong.  She instead started working at a salon in town.  She had taken cosmetology in BOCES in high school.  

I thought once she had been working for a bit and had saved enough she would then move out.  Wrong again.  I’ve asked her mother to see what her plans are for the future and if she plans on moving out on her own soon and my wife told me that she just wants to save as much as she can and keep living here.   My fiancé loves having her here, but I’ve been waiting so long to have the house be just my fiancé and I.   

I really feel like I’ve put my time in supporting her daughter and now especially with her having more than enough to move out on her own it’s time to push her out of the nest.  I’m not too concerned with her reaction.   To be blunt I don’t really care how she takes it.   My fiancé will probably be a little upset, but hopefully once the dust clears she will see that it’s for the best.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author of the given scenario is in the wrong. The situation involves the author considering kicking out his adult stepdaughter from their home. 

First, the author is in a long-term relationship with his fiancée, not married. They live together, and his stepdaughter is 19, an adult. The stepdaughter has been living with them since she was 16, but the author feels she should move out now that she's working and has the means. The stepdaughter isn't really close to the author, and even after he bought her a car, she didn't acknowledge him, which made him give up trying to build a relationship. The author's main issue is that he wants the house to be just for him and his fiancée, and he's frustrated that the stepdaughter isn't moving out on her own.

Now, the question is whether the author is in the wrong. From a legal standpoint, the stepdaughter is an adult, so she's responsible for her own living arrangements. The author isn't her parent; her mother is the one in the relationship. So legally, the stepdaughter could be expected to move out if she's an adult. But ethically, it's more complicated. The author has been financially supporting her, and now he wants her to leave because he wants their house back. 

The author's reasoning is that he tried to build a relationship, but she was indifferent. He feels he's done his part and wants her to become independent. However, there's a consideration of how the stepdaughter feels. She might not have a place to go, or she might rely on this arrangement. Also, the author's fiancée is okay with the stepdaughter staying, which might mean there's some emotional attachment or dependency there. 

The author's main argument is about his own needs and the desire for privacy. But as a stepparent, even if not a biological parent, there's a social responsibility to some extent. However, since the stepdaughter is an adult and the author isn't her legal guardian, he doesn't have the authority to force her out. The mother, being her parent, has more responsibility in that regard. The author might be right in expecting the stepdaughter to move out, but the way he's approaching it—being blunt and not caring how she reacts—might be harsh. 

Also, the author's motivation is personal: wanting the house to himself and his fiancée. That's valid, but it's important to consider whether the stepdaughter has other options. If she's planning to save money and hasn't found a place, kicking her out without support could be problematic. The author might be in the right in terms of not being obligated to keep her, but the manner in which he's doing it could be seen as insensitive.

So, balancing legal rights versus ethical responsibilities, the author might not be in the wrong legally, but ethically, there's a gray area. The answer depends on whether the question is about legal wrong or moral wrong. The question seems to be asking about moral wrong. In that case, the author's desire to prioritize his own needs over the stepdaughter's situation could be seen as wrong, especially if she's not ready to leave and there's no alternative provided. However, since she's an adult, he's not necessarily in the wrong for expecting her to move out on her own terms. But pushing her out abruptly without considering her circumstances might be where he's wrong.
